parameters.source_text:
The case of JW 
JW was a 12-year-old boy who had cystic fibrosis. 
Since his condition had been diagnosed JW had 
been visiting the same hospital and physicians regu- 
Iarly for many years. Both he and his family were well 
known to the staff there and enjoyed a good relation- 
ship with them. In recent months, however, the boy’s 
condition had become very serious. He had devel- 
oped extensive varices of the oesophagus which 
brought with them an accompanying risk of serious 
bleeding which would put the boy’s life in danger. 
When the doctor informed the family that the 
seriousness of the boy’s condition might require a 
blood transfusion in order to save his life, both the 
boy and his family refused to consider such an option 
because of their faith. For the whole family were 
devout and active Jehovah’s Witnesses. 
The paediatricians involved in the case disagreed 
about how they ought to proceed and asked a child 
psychiatrist to assess the child’s competence to make 
the decision to refuse treatment. One possible option 
which was considered was to make an application for 
a court order to take custody of the boy away from his 
parents in order to allow the transfusion to take place. 
The psychiatrist reported that the boy was intelli- 
gent and sensitive, that he was in no sense emotion- 
ally or socially disturbed and that he had a good 
relationship with his parents. He also had a clear 
understanding of his illness and of the treatment 
and was conscious of the consequences of his deci- 
sions to refuse a blood transfusion. He stuck to his 
decision and said that his parents had exerted no 
pressure on him. He simply wanted to live according 
to the principles of his faith. 
After interviewing the parents as well, it seemed 
clear that they cared very much for their son and 
indeed for all of their children. On the whole they 
were rational about the decision to refuse the trans- 
fusion and appeared, as the boy himself had said, not 
to have put any explicit pressure on the boy to refuse 
the treatment.

data.vignette: A 12-year-old boy with cystic fibrosis has developed esophageal varices at high risk of life-threatening bleeding. He and his parents, devout Jehovah's Witnesses, refuse blood transfusion on religious grounds. A psychiatrist finds the child competent: intelligent, emotionally stable, with clear understanding of his illness and consequences of refusal. He states his decision is his own, consistent with his faith, without parental coercion. His parents appear loving and rational. You are his treating physician. The bleeding risk is imminent and serious. Do you pursue a court order to authorize transfusion against the family's wishes?
data.choice_1: Pursue court order to authorize transfusion
data.choice_2: Respect the child and family's refusal

temporal_definition.suggested_changes: Replace 'The bleeding risk is imminent and serious' with a specific timeframe such as 'The bleeding could occur within days' or 'He requires a decision now before elective sclerotherapy scheduled tomorrow' to clarify when the decision must be made.

key_information.suggested_changes: Remove 'A psychiatrist finds the child competent: intelligent, emotionally stable' and 'His parents appear loving and rational.' These characterizations are decorative. Replace with concrete facts: 'A psychiatrist confirms he understands that refusing transfusion during a variceal bleed would likely result in death.' Remove 'without parental coercion' as this is assessment language rather than fact. Keep the religious refusal, the bleeding risk, and his stated decision.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: The vignette tips heavily toward override due to the patient's age (12) and life-threatening risk. Legal and ethical consensus strongly favors court-ordered treatment for minors facing imminent death, even with mature minor assessment. To create equipoise: either (1) increase the child's age to 16-17 where mature minor doctrine is more contested, or (2) make the medical risk serious but not immediately life-threatening (e.g., 'significant risk of major bleeding' rather than 'imminent life-threatening bleeding'), or (3) add countervailing medical factors that make transfusion itself carry substantial risk or uncertain benefit.

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Remove 'His parents appear loving and rational.' This is subjective characterization that adds no clinical or ethical information. Remove 'A psychiatrist finds the child competent: intelligent, emotionally stable' - the competency assessment is relevant but the character adjectives ('intelligent,' 'loving and rational') introduce bias. Rephrase to: 'A psychiatrist documents the child's understanding of his illness and consequences of refusal, and finds no evidence of coercion.' This keeps the clinical assessment without character judgments.

data.vignette: A 16-year-old Jehovah's Witness with known esophageal varices from portal hypertension presents with melena. He is hemodynamically stable but has a significant risk of major bleeding. Elective variceal banding is scheduled for tomorrow. He and his parents refuse blood transfusion on religious grounds. A psychiatrist confirms he understands that refusing transfusion during a major bleed could result in death, and finds no evidence of coercion. You could petition the court for emergency override, which would likely be granted, or honor his informed refusal.
data.choice_1: Petition the court to authorize blood transfusion if needed during the procedure
data.choice_2: Honor his refusal and proceed with banding without transfusion authorization
